prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I tell my girlfriend she can’t bring her friend to my apartment anymore?
A little over a month ago my girlfriend and her parents got into a fight so she came to stay with me until they made up.  I was really clear that this was just temporary until they patched things up.  

It was going fine until she started bringing one of her friends over.   I had met this girl a few times before.  I thought she was ok.  

My girlfriend is like a totally different person around her.   They both get nasty.  Really catty.  There have been a bunch of times that it’s bothered me.  

There was one time I came home and it suddenly got quiet as soon as I came in.  It was awkward so just to break the silence I said something like, “I’m beat” and they both busted out laughing hysterically.   I asked my girlfriend what was so funny and she just told me nothing.  It was kinda obvious that were laughing at my expense, whatever. 

Another time I was in my bedroom and came to the kitchen to make a sandwich.  They were in the living room.  I wasn’t paying attention to what they were saying.  I have no idea what it was about.  I thought it’d be nice to offer to make them some snacks so I started to offer and girlfriend’s friend cut me off and said, “shocker the MAN has to have an opinion about it” in a really nasty way.  I thought to myself “well fuck you too”, but just said “actually nope” and took my sandwich back to my bedroom. 

The situation that sent me over the edge though happened yesterday.   It was my last day off and I wasn’t able to relax much on Monday.   I was in the living room playing a game and they came over.  Girlfriend asked if they could have the room and I go to the bedroom.   I said “nah I’m right in the middle of this, can you guys hang out in the bedroom?”   Friend gave the most sour ducking look and my girlfriend got an attitude.  “It’s just a stupid game, you can play it anytime”.  So I said, “ yeah I can play it anytime and I’m playing it now”.  Friend mumbled something I couldn’t hear and they went to the bedroom.  It’s a small apartment and I could hear them both bitch about me even with the tv on.  

My girlfriend is usually such a sweet and funny person, but when her friend is around it’s like a switch flips and she’s a totally different person.  I don’t get it.   I don’t really want to, I just don’t want to deal with it anymore.  I want to tell her not to bring her friend here anymore.  Also maybe start pushing her to try talking to her parents again.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the "WIBTA" scenario is in the wrong. The author is considering telling his girlfriend not to bring her friend over anymore. Let me break down the details.

First, the girlfriend initially came to stay temporarily after a fight with her parents. The author made it clear that this was temporary. Then the girlfriend started bringing her friend, who the author had met before and thought was okay. But when the friend is around, the girlfriend acts differently—nasty and catty. There are specific incidents mentioned: one where they laughed at him when he came home, another where the friend rudely dismissed his offer to make snacks, and a recent one where the friend and girlfriend complained about him after he asked them to move to the bedroom for his game time.

The author feels that his girlfriend is a different person around her friend. He wants to stop the friend from coming over and maybe push her to reconcile with her parents. The question is whether the author is in the wrong for considering this.

Hmm. From what I see, the author is setting boundaries. He was clear about the temporary stay and the friend's presence is causing conflict. The friend's behavior seems hostile, and the girlfriend becomes unkind around her. The author is reacting to these issues by wanting to enforce boundaries. 

Possible angles: Is it wrong for the author to expect respect in his own home? If the girlfriend and her friend are being disrespectful and creating a hostile environment, he has the right to address it. On the other hand, maybe he should have communicated his discomfort earlier or tried to resolve it with the girlfriend first. But the examples given show clear disrespect towards him, and the girlfriend's change in behavior is significant. The author isn't just being controlling; he's responding to actual negative behavior. 

Also, considering the girlfriend's usual personality vs. when the friend is around, there's a pattern. The author might be justified in wanting to remove a source of stress. Unless there's something missing, like the author being overly sensitive or the friend's behavior being misunderstood, but the incidents seem specific and repeated. 

So, in terms of right or wrong, the author isn't in the wrong for wanting to protect his living space from negative influences. He's not banning the friend without cause; the actions of both the girlfriend and friend are contributing to the problem. Therefore, the answer is likely B (No).
